p: Climate change will be an important driver of biodiversity loss into the foreseeable future. Habitat degradation, phenological shifts and ecosystem change are expected to result in an increasing number of species of conservation concern (Walther etÂ al. 2002). Improved methods are needed to address the interactive effects of climate change and other, direct human impacts on wildlife populations. Such methods can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of management and recovery actions, and to balance the costs and benefits inherent to conservation planning.
